The ministers each went, but they were not seen. The ministers reported to the king, saying:

The people of the country all gathered like clouds, accompanying the great king together to the city. The news reached neighboring countries far and near, with praise.
The king then betrothed his daughter to MahÄmaudgalyÄyana. Although he received rewards and love, he had no arrogant or indulgent thoughts.

At that time, the caá¹‡á¸Äla tied a red flower to his neck, beat a bad-sounding drum, and was followed by bad people, holding a knife and frightening him like a Yama messenger, sending him to the cremation ground.

When he was about to be executed, no one was willing to kill him. The onlookers wept with grief, loving him as if he were their own relative, each uttering sorrowful words in search of the heavens and the Buddha.

At that time, when Great Medicine was about to be executed, he spoke these words. The messenger heard this and said to Great Medicine:

He replied:

The messenger took this message to inform the king. Although the king listened to the words, he still did not understand. He then ordered the messenger to go and summon Great Medicine. He asked:

He replied:
The words have profound meaning.

May the king listen well and briefly explain the meaning of the verse.

As for saying the king cannot be trusted, before the king had no cities or towns under his rule in the country, he only had food and drink in the inner palace. As for saying evil people are difficult to befriend, in the past there was a poor man who traveled to other lands as a guest, coming to the king's place to beg for a living. The king did not accept him, so he came to me. Seeing his poverty and cold, I gave him clothes and food to save his life;
He does not think of his debt of gratitude, now he comes to kill me.
As for saying secret matters should not be told to women, the king once announced to the people during a court session:
If there are secret matters, to whom can they be told?
Some said:
Parents, wife, children, and so on.
Explained in detail as above.

None of them can be trusted. The king should investigate carefully.
The peacock in the king's palace I did not eat. I had another bird cooked for my wife.

If you do not believe me, you can call her to come.
The king called the palace woman, and upon examination, she was no different.
As for saying I did not owe him barley flour, the king ordered the executioner to kill me. The man came and grabbed the hem of my robe, saying:

' The king heard the verse and examined the matter, knowing that MahÄmaudgalyÄyana was innocent, and joyfully released him, then treated him with great respect and made him a high minister.

He then took leave of the king and left, assuming the appearance of a brahmin. He held a pure water pot, wore a lucky thread, and was dressed in deerskin with three lines painted on his face. He went to his own city, wishing to find a wife.
On the road, at dusk, he saw a brahmin. They asked each other:

'He asked:

'He then took him back to his house and arranged it according to the Dharma.
MahÄmaitrÄyaá¹‡Ä«putra saw that the Brahmin's wife was not chaste, and after spending the night there, he wanted to leave in the morning.

On the way, in a wheat field, he saw a young girl with a dignified appearance, seemingly from a good family. He felt love and asked:
Wise one!

My name is ViÅ›ÄkhÄ.

MahÄmaitrÄyaá¹‡Ä«putra thought:

MahÄmaitrÄyaá¹‡Ä«putra then went to a wheat field, raised his hands high, and trampled the wheat with his feet. ViÅ›ÄkhÄ said:

He asked:

And she spoke two verses.

At that time, MahÄmaitrÄyaá¹‡Ä«putra entered through the side door, his body adorned with flower garlands, and came to the king. With a smile, he said to the king:
Your love and care for me is extremely deep, but as soon as I died, you immediately confiscated my belongings.
The king said:ğŸ”½What are you saying?
'This is not my request for wealth, but ViÅ›ÄkhÄ herself brought it and said:

MahÄmaudgalyÄyana said:
'If that is so, the King may open it to see what precious treasures there are.'
When the chest was opened, the six great ministers each came out from within.
The King asked the reason, and the six ministers replied:
'We, due to our desires, were deceived by a woman;
We beg the Great King's grace, we dare not do this again.'
The King said:
'The turning of the world is all due to desire, having suffered this humiliation, you should receive a heavy punishment.
You may return for now, I will consider it later.'
The king then sighed and said:
Alas, women!

They can have such chastity and extraordinary conduct, and their plans surpass others. This has never happened before. The great ministers and prime ministers have been humiliated to this extent, but because of this, they are able to restrain those who indulge in desires.
The king, being delighted, doubled the salary and emoluments of Visakha, and it became widely known in all countries.
At that time, the great king had this thought:
'Mahaphala has blessings and has gained such a wise wife.'
He then told Mahaphala:
'You should find a talented and wise wife for me, who can ensure the peace and stability of the country's governance internally and externally, so that I can simply sit back and relax.'
Mahaphala replied:

MahÄ-lekhÄ replied,
That is a neighboring country, and their affairs are like those of an enemy. First use skillful means, and then seek to reach them.
The king ordered the prime minister to go himself to propose marriage. When the ministers of that king saw the envoy arrive, they discussed together, saying,
King VetharÄ«á¹£Ä« has many troops and strength. If we marry together, our feelings and affairs will be close.

The envoy returned and reported to the king,
We have obtained the girl. On such-and-such a date, we will complete the rites.

Great King!
Please do not worry. I have a parrot named ViÅ›eá¹£a, who has great wisdom and is good at understanding human feelings. Send him to that city to observe and report back.

At that time, the parrot, having received the order, flew and arrived at that city. Perched on a treetop, he looked around to observe who could be consulted about communication coming and going.
Who was worthy of being entrusted with this matter?
In the end, there was not a single bird with whom he could discuss it.

I came from the north, from King ÅšrÄ«'s place. I was formerly a garden keeper. ÅšÄrikÄ was my wife. She is young, with an incomparably upright appearance, diligent, wise, and skilled in speech. She went out to play for a while and was caught by an eagle. Because of this, I am worried and my heart is like an arrow. I have been searching everywhere and have come here. I have no companion. He replied:

and was blown here by the wind.'

At that time, Saá¹ƒbhava saw that the king's family was making various kinds of exquisite pastries, with many different colors and all of them rare. After Saá¹ƒbhava saw this, he said to ÅšÄri:

Åšaá¹­a replied, saying:

At that time, the parrot flew up into the sky and soon arrived where MahÄmaudgalyÄyana was. He reported the matter in detail. MahÄmaudgalyÄyana then reported it all to the king in order and advised him not to go.

What did the king and MahÄmaudgalyÄyana plan to do together?

After MahÄmaudgalyÄyana and the king had done this, they sent a message saying:
'It's not that I can't fight with you, but since you are my father-in-law, you are a close relative. You should think carefully about the importance of preserving your life.
Now that you have come to me, you are not free to live. If you don't believe my words, you must witness it for yourself.

He then searched and found it all to be true. He knew the matter was different and withdrew his troops in the middle of the night. Having reached the city, he then killed all five hundred ministers, and had the sons of the ministers succeed their fathers' positions.
MahÄ-MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said to the king:

MahÄ-MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« led his troops to the country of PanchÄla and stopped in the garden. The king of that country then called for him to enter the city.

'I will not enter the city, but will stay at the minister's house for now.'
The king said:

The ministers said to the king:

The king then agreed and led the four troops to the country of VidhÄ“taya and surrounded the city.

At that time, MahÄ-upÄya knew that King PaÃ±caÅ›ikha had left by a certain road and was heading to VidhÄ“taya. MahÄ-upÄya found out that the king's precious treasures were all in a certain place, and that his daughter and the miraculous medicine were in the same place.
Dayaphaya then forcibly entered the palace, taking his daughter, the precious medicine, and various treasures, and leading his troops on a different route to return.
Having seen the king, he gathered the court officials and rejoiced immeasurably.
At that time, the envoy from the country of Pancala arrived and reported to the king:
The precious treasures and the woman have been taken away by others.
Having received the news, the king ordered the troops to return.
At that time, the king of this country made extensive arrangements for the wedding, and after the marriage was completed, he appointed the precious medicine as the chief consort.
At that time, King Pancala sent a messenger to deliver a letter to the precious medicine, saying:
I am worried and distressed, how could you not know? You should carefully investigate who spread this matter, and who mixed poison in the food to harm the king?
After the woman received the letter, she examined the matter and knew that it was Dayaphaya's parrot that transmitted the secret message. She sent a messenger to report to her father.

'All this is because the parrots observed what happened and went back and forth to report to each other, causing the chaos that destroyed the country and lost the state. The parrots should be brought here.'
The woman put the parrots in a cage and sent them to her father, the king. When the king saw the parrots, he became even more angry:
'Because of this useless bird, the country was lost and my parents died. Do not discuss it any further, but it should be killed immediately.'
The bird then bowed and said to the king:

The king said:
'Follow their death method and end their lives.'
The butcher asked:
'What is the death method?'

The butcher did as he was told, and after he let go, the parrot flew up into the sky, shook its feathers, and set fire to the empty room, burning it to nothing. It then went into the pond to wash and bathe, soared through the clouds, and flew to VaidiÅ›Ä.

The parrot explained in detail, and MahÄ-upÄya was delighted.

Because of this parrot, it burned my palace.

The girl then sent the parrot back as instructed.
When the king saw it, he was very angry and ordered that its feathers be plucked and it be boiled in hot water.
The butcher plucked its feathers and threw it out onto the eaves, saying:
You can go.
A flying hawk saw it, picked it up, and carried it to a shrine.
The hawk was about to eat it, but the parrot told the hawk:ğŸ”½You should know that I am a messenger of the king.

' The guard then took this message to inform the great king, and the king said:

' After many days, the owl ate the raw meat, and the parrot ate the sesame. The feathers gradually grew in, and it became able to fly. It wanted to leave and told the guard:
'You should tell the king: For so many days, you have made offerings to me. There is one more thing you cannot disobey.
The king, the palace, the city, the moat, the officials and the people, all shave their heads and come to me. I will bestow upon them inexhaustible wealth and happiness.

The messenger reported to the king, and the king immediately followed suit, shaving off all his beard and hair and going to the temple to worship the feet of the heavenly deity, seeking mercy and repentance.

All things must be reciprocated, there is nothing that is not repaid;
You plucked the hair on my body, I will now shave you in return.
Having said this, it beat its wings and flew away.
It went to where MahÄmaudgalyÄyana was and asked:
Why are you so slow that you make me feel strange?
It then fully explained what had happened, and when MahÄmaudgalyÄyana heard it, he was extremely delighted and reported it to the king in detail. The king sighed in wonder and said:
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana!
You truly have blessings, and the relatives you have attracted are all wise.
ViÅ›ÄkhÄ's spiritual wisdom surpasses that of humans, and the parrot is difficult to match in the world.
Later, on another occasion, the king had this thought:
Among all the ministers, who is the wisest?
He ordered the ministers to each be given a dog to raise and feed, and to teach it to speak human language within a certain period of time.
The ministers took the dogs back to their homes and doubled their care, but there was no method to make them speak human language.

They then made a pact to gamble five hundred gold coins. The son returned and reported to his father:
I said:
The floating stone, gambling five hundred gold coins.
His father said:
You should not show the stone, but give the five hundred coins to those people.
In the home of MahÄmaudgalyÄyana, a monkey was taught to be skilled in music. He told his son:
You can ask the people at the assembly:
Who has seen anything strange?
After others have spoken, you should say:

The people said:
Before there was no floating stone, and he has already been fined five hundred gold coins.
Now if it is false again, he will pay one thousand coins.
If it is true, I will give him one thousand coins.
Then he took the monkey to the king's place, and ordered it to play music. This was all accomplished, and he gave out one thousand coins to pay the gambling fee.
The king said:
I have never seen such a thing.
He was greatly delighted and bestowed many precious treasures, saying:
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana's wisdom is the foremost among the assembly.
At that time, there was a brahmin in this city who was wise and intelligent, learned in the four Vedas. He married a wife and soon had a daughter, who was beautiful and named Udumbara.
The brahmin made a vow for himself, saying:
'If there is a man who studies with me and is equal to me, I will give my wonderful daughter to him in marriage.'

The daughter gradually grew up. In this country, a brahmin gave birth to a son whose appearance was ugly, with eighteen kinds of unsightly features. His parents, upon seeing him, were extremely unhappy and named him 'Ugly Features.' Even though he gradually reached adulthood, he was not taught to study, because this child was ugly and would bring shame upon them.
As the child grew up, he resented his lack of knowledge and thus entered the city to seek learning.

'I have come to request instruction. Please have compassion for me.
The brahmin agreed, and in a short time he had learned all the treatises.
The brahmin then had this thought:
I made a vow before that if there was anyone who could master my craft, I would give him my daughter in marriage.

if one goes against one's heart, one cannot be reborn in the heavens.
Even if people laugh at me, I have no regret.
He then prepared the proper rites and betrothed his daughter to him.
The girl's majestic light was awe-inspiring, causing the ugly one to dare not approach.
The ugly one thought:
I am now a guest here, feeling timid and fearful. I should take her back to my own place and do as I please.
At that time, Uá¸umbara, seeing the ugly one, felt displeased and had this thought:
I am endowed with beauty, while my husband is ugly. People will laugh at me. What face will I have in life?
The evil-natured one then took her back to his place. On the way, their provisions ran out. They came to the side of a pond and were hungry.
At that time, a traveler had some flour and water to drink. Udumbara begged for it. He gave a little to her. The evil-natured one took it all to one side and ate it himself. Udumbara said:
'You should share some to fill your hunger.'
The evil-natured one said:
'The ancient sages had a rule that women should not drink flour.
That is why I did not give it to you.'
Next, in the wilderness, they suddenly found some discarded meat. The evil-natured one took it to eat and did not give it to Udumbara, saying:
'This is also something the ancient sages did not allow women to eat.'
Udumbara thought:
'I have no blessings and virtues. My parents married me to this evil person.'
She deeply regretted it.
Next, they came to an udumbara tree. The evil-natured one climbed the tree to pick fruit to eat. His wife said:
'You should beat it and eat together. It is not right to eat alone.'
The husband said, You can pick the ripe ones.
The wife replied, You can pick the ripe ones.
The husband said, If you want the ripe ones, climb the tree yourself and pick them.
Out of hunger, she then climbed the tree, picked the fruit, and ate it.
Seeing this, the husband thought, I have no share, yet I have obtained such a flighty wife who climbs high trees, picks fruit, and eats it herself.
Moreover, I cannot even take care of myself, so who can support this useless wife?
Disgusted, he took down the thorns, surrounded the tree, and left.
At that time, King Madhu was out hunting and came to the edge of the forest. The woman, having lost her husband, was in great distress and cried out in grief.

Hearing her cries, the king ordered, This is an empty forest, so who is crying?ğŸ”½The woman replied, I am the wife of a fruit picker. My husband went to pick fruit and has not returned. I am worried and afraid, so I cry out in grief.
Following the sound, he eventually arrived at the side of the woman Udumbara. Seeing her appearance, he suspected she was a celestial maiden or some kind of spirit. He asked:

The woman replied in verse:

At that time, the king had people support her down from the tree. Their joy was unhindered, as if they had known each other for a long time. He then took her in the same carriage and brought her into the palace.
At that time, the evil-looking man followed the road, feeling regretful:
What I did was improper. How can I abandon my young wife alone in the wilderness?
I should go back and get her to return home with me.
When he arrived under the tree, he did not see Udumbara. The others told him:
The king took her away. They were riding together and entered the palace.
When the evil-looking man heard this, he became even more sorrowful. He went to the king's gate but had no way to enter.
He saw the man carrying bricks and immediately followed him in, hoping to see his wife having fun with the king. He thought:
What chance will I have to briefly speak with her?
He then used another matter as an excuse and spoke a verse in a loud voice, saying:
You are on a golden bed, adorned with flowers and freckles;
You do not enjoy yourself with me, the craftsman holds a knife and axe.
The woman heard this and replied:
Hungry and thirsty, I went to the pond, seeking gruel and drink from you;
You said the woman was unsuitable, and I have long resented you, beating the drum.
Traveling together through the wilderness, we ate meat without sharing it;
Thinking of this, I became emaciated. When dancing, you need to keep the beat.
Climbing the udumbara tree myself, the ripe fruit was not shared with me;
Thinking of this, my body and mind are haggard, and my two breasts hang down in front.
The evil one replied:
You do not remember me, with my great learning and many talents and wisdom,
For a slight lapse in serving you, you abandoned me and left for a long time.
Climbing a mountain to die by falling, or taking poison to end my life,
The sin of killing will be yours, O clever one, holding the chisel firmly.'
The woman replied:
I can die on the mountain peak as I please, or take poison to end my life as I wish,
But since you treat me with contempt, how can I beat the drum?

In this case, the fourth line of each verse is all about taking past events of the previous day and making them into words and phrases, intending to confuse people, and has no other meaning. At that time, the two people relied on other words to answer each other, and the king then asked:
'What is the meaning of the words spoken by the queen?
I have heard but do not understand, please explain it.'
Uá¸um then told the king in detail:
'This is my husband whom my parents married me to. He has great wisdom and thoroughly understands the four branches of knowledge. He is now seeking me and has come here.'
The king said:
'You should remain silent and not bother to speak with him.
Moreover, what do you intend to do today?
Do you want to continue your former love with him?'
She replied:
'How could there be such a thing?

However, this brahmin is proficient in many spells and incantations, so we should not hastily punish him.'
The king then reported the matter to MahÄmaudgalyÄyana, who said:
'May the king not worry. I will make the queen love and cherish the king, while the brahmin's appearance is lowly and the queen's radiance is outstanding, so he will not dare to approach her.'
Then MahÄmaudgalyÄyana told the brahmin:
'Why have you come to the palace? What do you seek?'
He replied:
'My wife was taken into the palace by the great king.'
He asked:
Do you recognize your wife?
He replied:
I recognize her.
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana said:
Summon all five hundred palace women before you, and if she is your wife, you may take her.
If you make a mistake, I will cut off your head with a sword.

As you command.

The king ordered the palace women to all adorn themselves and come to him. They all gathered like the five hundred celestial maidens in the palace of Åšakra, Devendra. Following Utpala, they all went to the king's place.

Do you recognize your wife?
Seeing the extraordinary adornments, like a dragon or snake bound by spells, not uttering a word, and like the sun shining, not daring to look directly at her.
At that time, the brÄhman looked from afar, and all the women passed by. There was a maid behind, her form like a hungry ghost. The brÄhman grabbed her and said:
This is my wife.
The great medicine said:
If this is your wife, take her away as you please.
He then took her and spoke a verse, saying:
The superior person still loves the superior, the middling person loves the middling by himself;
I am a hungry ghost in form, and still pity you, a hungry ghost.
Abandoning this heavenly palace, we will follow each other to the home of ghosts;
The color and type are just right, seeking others is impossible.
Later, for some slight offense, the king was displeased and did not speak to him.

The king and the palace women went to the garden to play all day. When it was time to return in the evening, she went to sleep until midnight before she remembered.
At that time, the monkey saw the pearl and took it up to a high tree. The king ordered a messenger to go quickly and retrieve the pearl, but the messenger could not get it.
At that time, a beggar had picked up leftover food and was about to leave the garden. The guard then grabbed him:
No one else has entered. Return my pearl necklace!
He replied:
I am a beggar. I did not see any necklace.
He was then beaten and taken to the prison warden.
The beggar thought to himself:
I should devise a plan. If I stay here any longer, I will starve to death.
He said to the guard:
I obtained the pearl necklace and gave it to the son of a certain elder.
The guard then arrested the son of the elder and shackled his feet with the same wooden board.
Whenever it was mealtime, the son of the elder would bring many delicacies. The beggar asked for some, and the son scolded him:
It was because of you that I was brought here. I cannot give it to you.
After the son had finished his meal and wanted to leave, he turned around and said:
My time has not yet come. I cannot go with you.
The beggar then spoke to him with loving words, saying:
Come with me, and I will bring you peace and happiness.
The prince replied:
Make a vow, and I will follow your words.
The beggar then made a vow and they left together.
The prince told his family:
From tomorrow onwards, always bring food for two people.
The beggar, because of this, felt joyful and thought:
In the past, I wandered all over the city and still could not get coarse food to fill my belly. Now I am eating delicacies, what more could I want?
However, I cannot lie down alone.
